column2: a tree representation of a program that is abstracted from the details of a particular programming language and its surface syntax.
a state of a finite automaton in which the input string is accepted as being a member of the language recognized by the automaton.
see alignment.
a set of symbols used in the definition of a language.
a case where more than one interpretation is possible.
a grammar that allows some sentence or string to be generated or parsed in more than one way ( i.e.
column3: with distinct parse trees).

column2: the number of arguments of a function.
a specification of the order in which operations should be performed when two operators of the same precedence are adjacent. Most operators are left-associative
column3: e.g. the expression A - B - C should be interpreted as ((A - B) - C).

column2: a formalism for describing parsers
column3: especially for natural language. Similar to a finite automaton
column4: but augmented in that arbitrary tests may be attached to transition arcs
column6: and structure-building actions may be executed as an arc is traversed.

column2: a self-balancing binary search tree.
the address of the beginning of a data area. This address is added to a relative address or offset to compute an absolute address.
a data type that is implemented in computer hardware instructions
column3: such as integer or real.

column2: Backus-Naur Form
column3: a syntax for writing context-free grammars that describe computer languages.

column2: a parsing method in which input words are matched against the right-hand sides of grammar productions in an attempt to build a parse tree from the bottom towards the top.
a situation
column3: e.g. in compiling a program
column4: where one error causes many reported errors. For example
column5: failure to declare a variable may cause an error every time that variable is referenced.

column2: to coerce a given value to be of a specified type. In the C-like languages
column3: a cast is specified by putting the desired type inside parentheses ahead of an expression: d = (double) i;

column2: the hierarchy of formal language types: regular ⊂ context free ⊂ context sensitive ⊂ recursively enumerable; each is a proper subset of the next class.
a kind of parser
column3: due to Cocke
column4: Kasami
column6: that efficiently produces all possible parses of an input. Also written CYK.

column2: the phase of a compiler in which executable output code is generated from intermediate code.
in a hash table
column3: a case in which a symbol has the same hash function value as another symbol.

column2: making a sequence that consists of the elements of a first sequence followed by those of a second sequence.
a grammar in which the left-hand side of each production consists of a single nonterminal symbol.
a contiguous area of memory
column3: specified by its base address and size. Data within the area are referenced by the base address of the area and the offset
column4: or relative address
column5: of the data within the area.

column2: a statement in a programming language that provides information to the compiler
column3: such as the structure of a data record
column4: but does not specify executable code.

column2: a list of steps that shows how a sentence in a language is derived from a grammar by application of grammar rules.
a finite automaton that has at most one transition from a state for each input symbol and no empty transitions. Abbreviated DFA.
rules that allow an ambiguous situation to be resolved to a single outcome
column3: e.g. rules of operator precedence.

column2: a scalar type consisting of a finite set of enumerated values
column3: e.g. type boolean = (false
column4: true);.

column2: grammars that denote the same language.
a grammar production
column3: as in a Yacc grammar
column4: that is executed if no other (legal) production matches the input.

column2: an abstract computer consisting of an alphabet of symbols
column3: a finite set of states
column4: a starting state
column6: and transition rules that specify transitions from one state to another depending on the input symbol. The machine begins in the starting state; for each input symbol
column7: it makes a transition as specified by the transition rules. If the automaton is in an accepting state at the end of the input

column2: a formal specification of a language
column3: consisting of a set of nonterminal symbols
column4: a set of terminal symbols or words
column5: and production rules that specify transformations of strings containing nonterminals into other strings.

column2: a deterministic function that converts converts a symbol or other input to a pseudo-randomized integer value.
a table that associates key values with data by use of a hash function.
a form of hash table in which the hash code denotes a bucket or set of entries whose keys hash to that value.
an expression written with an operator between its operand
column3: e.g. a + b . cf. prefix
column4: postfix.

column2: placement of a new data item in its proper position in an ordered sequence
column3: such as a list
column4: array

column2: an internal language used as the representation of a program during compilation
column3: such as trees or quadruples. The source language is translated to intermediate language
column4: which is then translated to the object language.

column2: zero or more occurrences of a grammar item; indicated by a superscript *.
L(G)
column3: the set of strings that can be derived from a grammar
column4: beginning with the start symbol.

column2: a method of modifying a grammar to eliminate left recursion.
in a grammar
column3: a case where A ⇒ A α for some nonterminal symbol A. In top-down parsing
column4: left recursion will cause an infinite recursion. Also

column2: describes operators in an arithmetic expression such that if there are two adjacent occurrences of operators with the same precedence
column3: the left one should be done first. Thus
column4: a - b + c means (a - b) + c. Most operators are left-associative.

column2: a derivation in which the leftmost nonterminal of the string is replaced at each step.
a basic symbol in a language; e.g.
column3: a variable name would be a lexeme for a grammar of a programming language.

column2: lexical analyzer.
parsing and conversion to internal form of the simplest elements of a language
column3: usually specified by a regular grammar
column4: such as variable names

column2: a convention in a block-structured programming language that a variable can only be referenced within the block in which it is defined; thus
column3: the scope of a variable is determined at compile time. Also called static scoping. cf. dynamic scoping.

column2: the fractional part of a floating-point number; also
column3: significand.

column2: Not a Number
column3: a floating-point value that does not represent a valid number. This could result from use of uninitialized data (if memory is initialized to NaN's)
column4: arithmetic performed on a NaN
column5: or an undefined operation such as 0/0. A NaN may be quiet
column7: in which case its generation or use generates a CPU exception.

column2: a finite automaton that has multiple state transitions from a single state for a given input symbol
column3: or that has a null transition
column4: not requiring an input symbol. Abbreviated NFA.

column2: a symbol that names a phrase in a grammar.
the output language of a compiler.
the ability to observe the state of a system. For software
column3: the provision of built-in code to allow the internal operations of a program to be easily observed.

column2: the location of data relative to the start of a data area.
a data value upon which an operation is performed.
a symbol that denotes an operation to be performed on data in an expression.
transformation of a program to produce a program whose input-output behavior is equivalent to that of the original program
column3: but that has lower cost
column4: e.g. faster execution time.

column2: the assignment of multiple meanings to an operator
column3: depending on the type of data to which it is applied; e.g.
column4: the symbol + could represent integer addition

column2: insertion of unused storage in order to achieve storage alignment.
a data structure that shows how a statement in a language is derived from the context-free grammar of the language; it may be annotated with additional information
column3: e.g. for compilation purposes.

column2: the process of reading a source language
column3: determining its structure
column4: and producing intermediate code for it.

column2: a phase of a compiler or assembler in which the entire source program (in its original form or some later representation) is processed.
a way of writing expressions in which an operator appears after its operands: ab+.
an ordering of operators that specifies that certain operators should be performed before others when no ordering is otherwise specified.
1. a contiguous set of symbols at the beginning of a string. 2. a way of writing expressions in which an operator appears before its operands: +ab.
an order of visiting trees
column3: in which a node is examined first
column4: followed by recursive examination of its children

column2: a rule of a context-free grammar
column3: specifying that a nonterminal symbol can be replaced by another string of symbols.

column2: a program or abstract device that can read a string of symbols and decide whether the string is a member of a particular language.
a data area consisting of contiguous component fields
column3: which may be of different types.

column2: a method of writing a parser in which a grammar rule is written as a procedure that recognizes that phrase
column3: calling subroutines as needed for sub-phrases and producing a parse tree or other data structure as output.

column2: in a grammar for a shift-reduce parser
column3: a case in which an input might be reduced by more than one production.

column2: in shift-reduce parsing
column3: the reduction of items at the top of the stack to a phrase that encompasses those items.

column2: an algebraic expression that denotes a regular language. Regular expressions are usually easier to write than an equivalent regular grammar.
a grammar that denotes a regular language; its productions can only have on the right-hand side either a terminal string or a terminal string followed by a single nonterminal.
a language described by a regular grammar
column3: or recognizable by a finite automaton
column4: e.g. a simple item such as a variable name or a number in a programming language.

column2: 1. in a hash table storage scheme
column3: to calculate a new hash value for an item when the previous hash value caused a collision with an existing item. 2. the algorithm used to calculate the new hash value.

column2: a word in a programming language that is reserved for use as part of the language and may not be used as an identifier.
an operator in an arithmetic expression such that if there are two adjacent occurrences of operators with equal precedence
column3: the right one should be done first.

column2: a data type that occupies a fixed amount of storage.
the meaning of a statement in a language. cf. syntax.
in a grammar for a shift-reduce parser
column3: a case in which an input might either be shifted onto the stack or reduced.

column2: a parser that operates by alternately shifting input elements onto the top of a stack or reducing a group of elements from the top of the stack to form a larger element representing a phrase.
Signaling Not a Number
column3: a special value defined by IEEE floating point. An attempt to do arithmetic on a SNaN will cause a processor fault and halt execution; if an array is initialized to SNaN values
column4: this can detect errors of uninitialized data at no runtime cost.

column2: s
column3: the initial
column4: or sentence nonterminal symbol S of a grammar.

column2: the assignment of memory locations to data and program code.
a sequence of symbols or characters.
a contiguous subsequence of a sequence
column3: e.g. 1..10 is a subrange of integer.

column2: a sequence of symbols that matches a contiguous subsequence of another string.
a sequence of symbols at the end of a string.
a data structure that associates a name (symbol) with information about the named object.
the rules by which legitimate statements can be constructed. cf. semantics.
in parsing a programming language
column3: building the translation of a statement as directed by the syntactic form of the program.

column2: a method of translating statements
column3: e.g. in a programming language
column4: such that the translation of a phrase is built up from the translations of its components.

column2: a symbol in a phrase structure grammar that is a part of the language described by the grammar
column3: such as a word or character of the language. cf. nonterminal symbol.

column2: an occurrence of a word
column3: name
column4: or sequence of characters having a meaning as a unit in a language.

column2: a predictive form of parsing
column3: such as recursive descent
column4: in which the parse tree of a statement is constructed starting at the root (sentence symbol).

column2: a description of a kind of variables
column3: including a set of possible values and a set of operations.

column2: an operator that makes a type from other types
column3: e.g. array or record.

column2: a lattice structure that shows which types are higher or derivable from others
column3: e.g. float is higher than integer. When an operation is specified on different types
column4: the arguments may be coerced to the least upper bound of the two types in the lattice.

column2: an element of computer memory that can hold a value.
